In 2007, Jilma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Jilma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 5th loan from PMPC and the second with Kiva. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Cresencia

texts.en:
Cresencia A. is from the village of Owaon. She is 45 years old. She is married and has three school-aged and three adult children. To make a living, she raises pigs for sale. Cresencia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns an average of approximately $46 a month from this activity. 

In 2007, Cresencia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Cresencia is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell in the future. This will be her 5th loan from PMPC and her second with KIVA. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more piglets

loans.name: Srey Touch Nuon Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey Touch Soun is the president of a village bank loan that consists of sixteen people located in Chheu Teal Phluos village in Takeo province. The members will use this loan to purchase supplies, equipment, and other items to support their own different purposes. 

Mrs. Srey Touch Soun is 28 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to study or work. She and her husband, Mr. Borey Chea, are farmers who own a two-hectare field to grow crops. They face a problem because their field has infertile soil. Thus, Mrs. Srey Touch Soun decided to ask for a loan from AMK to buy fertilizer to support her farming.  

Aside from farming, Mr. Borey Chea is a fisherman who can earn a small income to help support his family.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: María Dolores

texts.es: María Dolores G. de 47 años de edad, reside en el municipio de San Francisco goteras, ubicado en el departamento Morazán. Vive junto a su esposo y una nieta de 8 años de edad, la cual está a cargo por completo de María. Ella posee una venta de ropa para niños, mujeres y hombres, así mismo vende zapatos. Ella comercializa sus productos desde su casa y así mismo los vende de forma ambulante entre sus vecinos, y personas de otras colonias. Ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar más ropa en diferentes estilos y colores, de manera que pueda obtener mayor clientela, así mismo comprar más zapatos. Todo esto lo hace con el deseo de ver prosperar su negocio y así mismo su economía familiar, ya que su esposo es empleado de una empresa privada pero a pesar de esto sus ganancias en muchas ocasiones no dan abasto con todo los gastos, razón por la que María ha decidido solicitar el préstamo a Integral, con la esperanza de poder mejorar su negocio y solventar todo lo que a su esposo se le dificulta. A pesar que María cuenta con una familia pequeña, ella es una mujer muy trabajadora la cual se esfuerza día con día por tener una mejor vida.
texts.en:
Maria Dolores Garcia, 47 years old, lives in the outskirts of the town of San Francisco, which is located in the Morazán area. She lives with her husband and 8-year-old granddaughter, for whom Maria is completely responsible. She sells clothing for children, women, and men and also sells shoes. She sells her products from her house and also sells them as walking vendor among her neighbors and people from other towns. She is seeking a loan through which she can buy more clothing in different styles and colors; in this way she can acquire a bigger clientele, and she will also buy more shoes. She does all this with the desire to see her business and also her family economy prosper, since her husband is an employee of a private business, but in spite of this, his earnings often aren't enough to cover all the expenses. For this reason, Maria has decided to apply for a loan at Integral, with the hope of being able to improve her business and pay for everything that is difficult for her husband. In spite of the fact that Maria has a small family, she is a very hardworking woman who tries hard every day to have a better life.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing to sell

location.town: San Francisco Gotera, departamento de Morazán

loans.name: Kedwin Roger

texts.es: Kedwin Roger A. V. de 28 años de edad, reside en el departamento de San Miguel. Vive junto a su hermano de 21 años de edad, dos sobrinos de 8 y 4 años de edad quienes estudian, y junto a su abuela de 80 años de edad. Desde hace 3 años que Kedwin se dedica a la venta de medicinas y vitaminas, logrando obtener mucha clientela debido a que esta es la única venta de este tipo de productos que hay en el lugar. Las personas acuden a su casa a comprar las medicinas, así mismo confían mucho en él ya que es una persona muy responsable, quien vende los productos medicinales en muy bueno estado. Él solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda invertir en su negocio comprando medicinas, las cuales satisfagan la demanda de sus clientes, ya que para Kedwin es de mucha importancia complacer a sus clientes debido a que reconoce el valor que los ellos tienen para él. Así mismo Kedwin solicita el préstamo a Integral, con el deseo de aumentar sus ventar y poder brindarles una vida mejor a sus sobrinos y a su abuela. Él es un joven muy emprendedor y visionario quien espera seguir adelante y obtener una vida mejor.
texts.en:
Kedwin Roger A. Vásque, 28, lives in the department of San Miguel. He lives with his 21-year-old brother, his 8 and 4-year-old nephews whom are in school, and with his 80-year-old grandmother. For the past three years Kedwin has worked selling medicine and vitamins. He has been able to obtain many customers because his is the only business that sells these products in the area. People come to his house to buy the medicines and they trust him as he is a very responsible person who sells high quality products. He is asking for a loan to invest in his business by buying more medicines so that he can meet his customers' demands. Kedwin is requesting this loan from Integral (Kiva Field Partner) with the hope of increasing his sales and improving the lives of his nephews and grandmother. He is a very enterprising and visionary young man who hopes to get ahead and lead a better a life.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy medicines

loans.name: Marleny De La Cruz

texts.es: Marleny De La Cruz M. F. de 32 años de edad, reside en el departamento de San Salvador, lugar en el cual vive junto a su esposo y sus dos hijos menores de edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar.  Marleny posee una panadería, en la cual se encarga de elaborar el pan, junto a su esposo quien es su mano derecha en el negocio, trabajan arduamente día con día para lograr entregar todos los pedidos a tiempo, responsabilidad la cual les ha permitido contar con una gran cantidad de clientes. Desde hace 4 años que Marleny posee esta panadería en la cual poco a poco se han ido ganando la confianza de sus clientes, y que a pesar de ser poco tiempo posee muy buenas referencias ya que su pan tiene muy buen sabor y es de muy buena calidad. Marleny solicita un préstamo a Integral con el fin de poder obtener el dinero necesario para comprar harina, manteca, azúcar, miel y otros utensilios lo cuales se utilizan para hornear el pan, así mismo desea poder comprar la harina por mayor, ya que en la actualidad ha subido de precio, y comprándola en grandes cantidades, logra obtenerla más barata. Marleny desea mucho prosperar junto a su esposo en el negocio, ya que es esta la única fuente de ingresos con la que cuentan, es por ello de mucha importancia mantenerla a flote y poder invertir lo más posible en ella para que genere mayores ingresos para beneficio de toda su familia.
texts.en:
Marleny De La Cruz M. F., 32, lives in the department of San Salvador with her husband and her two dependent children who go to school. Marleny owns a bakery and is responsible for making bread. Her husband is her right-hand man at the business and they work hard everyday to ensure that all their orders are delivered on time. Their responsible nature has resulted in a strong client base. Marleny has owned this business for 4 years and slowly but surely she has earned the trust of her customers. Despite only being open for a few years, she has many good references and her bread is known for its good flavor and high quality.

Marleny is asking for a loan from Integral (Kiva Field Partner) so she can have the money necessary to buy flour, butter, sugar, honey and other materials for baking bread. She wants to buy flour in bulk because flour prices have gone up and buying in larger quantities allows her to get a cheaper price. Marleny wants to find success with her husband with their business as it is their only source of income. Therefore it is very important for it to stay afloat and for them to be able to invest as much as possible in it so that they can increase their earnings which benefit their entire family.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy materials for making bread

loans.name: Mirna Consuelo

texts.es: Mirna Consuelo M. S. de 40 años reside en Armenia, ubicado en el departamento de Sonsonate. Vive junto a su única hija la cual le ayuda en el negocio. Mirna posee una venta de medicina natural, la cual comercializa a las afueras del mercado de Armenia. Desde hace muchos años que ella se dedica a este tipo de trabajo en el cual se inicio debido a la enorme necesidad a la que se enfrentaba junto a su hija, la cual ha dependido de ella toda su vida, ya que Mirna ha tenido que trabajar muy arduamente por sacarla adelante, ya que ella es madre soltera. Ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad de medicinas, sobre todo aquellas las cuales tienen más demanda por parte de las personas lo que es muy importante para Mirna ya que de esta manera complace a sus clientes y se asegura que sean constantes en las compras con ella. Mirna es una mujer muy trabajadora, la cual tiene grandes deseos de seguir adelante, mejorar su negocio, de manera que pueda obtener mayor ganancias, y así obtener una mejor estabilidad económica, teniendo una vida más estable y de esta manera seguir adelante con su hija quien es la que le da las fuerzas necesarias y la incentiva a querer ser mejor cada día.
texts.en:
Mirna Consuelo M. S., 40 years old, lives in Armenia, located in the Sonsonate district. She lives with her only daugher, who helps her in the business. Mirna sells natural medicines outside the market in Armenia. For many years she has done this kind of work, which she began because of the enormous needs which confronted her and her daughter, who has depended on her for her entire life. Mirna has had to work very hard to bring her up, since she is a single mother. She is applying for a loan so that she will be able to buy a bigger quantity of medicines, especially those for which people have the greatest demand, which is very important for Mirna, since in this way she satisfies her clients and assures herself that they will be her steady customers. Mirna is a very hard-working woman who has great desires to advance herself and improve her business so that she can obtain better earnings and thus greater economic stability, have a more stable life and thus advance herself and her daughter, who is the one who gives her the necessary strength and the incentive to want to be better every day.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy medicines to sell

loans.name: Kelin Victoria

texts.es: Kelin Victoria P. L. de 28 años, vive en Ciudad Arce, ubicado en el departamento de La Libertad. Vive junto a su única hija de 9 años de edad, la cual se dedica a estudiar. Kelin posee una venta de tortillas, las cuales son parte de la dieta diaria de los salvadoreños y es consumida tanto en el mediodía como en la noche o incluso en los tres tiempos de comida. Este ha demostrado ser un negocio muy rentable, en el cual ella se encarga de elaborar las tortillas, que posteriormente las personas llegan a comprar a su casa de habitación. Así mismo para obtener algunas ganancias extras, ella vende ropa usada para niños, hombre y mujeres, la cual es exportada de Los Estados Unidos.  Kelin solicita un préstamo a Integral a través del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para comprar maíz por mayor y así mismo comprar mayor cantidad de ropa en diferentes, tallas, estampados, colores y estilos, lo que le permita obtener más clientela y de esta manera obtener mayores ganancias. Kelin es una joven quien ha logrado salir adelante pese a todas las dificultades a las que se ha enfrentado, es por esto que su mayor deseo es poder hacer crecer  su negocio lo cual le permita brindarle una mayor estabilidad económica a su hija y así mismo darle un mejor futuro para ella.
texts.en:
Kelin Victoria P. L. is 28 years old and lives in Arce City, located in the area of La Libertad. She lives with her 9 year old daughter, who is a student. Kelin works selling tortillas, which are part of the daily diet of Salvadorans and are eaten as often at noon as they are at night or at any of the three mealtimes. Her business has proven itself to be very profitable. She is in charge of preparing the tortillas, and people then come to her home to buy them. In order to earn extra income, she also sells used clothing for men, women, and children, that has been imported from the United States. Kelin is asking Integral for a loan to buy corn in bulk and also to buy a greater quantity of clothing in different sizes, prints, colors, and styles, which will allow her to get more customers and increase earnings. Kelin is a young woman who has gotten ahead despite the difficulties she has faced--which have made her biggest goal to grow her business in order to provide more financial stability for her daughter and to give her a better future.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn and clothing to sell

location.town: Ciudad Arce en el departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Leticia's Group

texts.en: Leticia A. is from the village of San Pablo, Alicia, IsabeL.. She is 52 years old and is the group leader of a twenty-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Leticia is married and has four adult children. She owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Leticia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used for a hog-raising business. This loan will be her sixth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use for a hog-raising business

loans.name: Primitiva

texts.en:
Primitiva M. is a trusted member of Kiva partner, ASHI, in the Philippines. She has been receiving loans since she became a member in 2009, and has been able to sustain a small business that provides her family with their basic needs.
Primitiva buys and sells “amakan” (a word which, in Antiqueño dialect, refers to woven bamboo strips that are used to dry rice under the heat of the sun). She started this business with her first loan last year. In partnership with her husband, Lino, they transport this product to other provinces through “RORO", or roll on, roll of – a means of transport whereby vehicles that carry passengers and products, particularly buses, roll on a barge to travel across the ocean and roll off once their destination is reached.
Primitiva is happily engaged in this business activity with her husband. Although their profit is still small, she and her husband enjoy working together to achieve their dream of helping their children, even in a small way. Primitiva and her husband agreed to request another loan to finance their plan of expanding their business. They want to put up a small warehouse for storing the amakan they sell.

loans.use: To purchase more "amakan" to sell

loans.name: Nieves' Group

texts.en:
Nieves I. is from the village of Agliam. She is 39 years old. Nieves is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Nieves I.'s Group.

Nieves is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Nieves owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Nieves has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $44 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Nieves joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nieves has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Nieves is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Chan's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Y. Chan is from Chheu Teal Phluos village in Takeo province. She is 48 years old and the president of a village bank group loan offered by Kiva partner, AMK. The 18 members of this group loan will use their loans for different purposes.
Mrs. Y. Chan is married and has two children, one of whom is a Khmer noodle seller while the other still attends the local school. Her husband, Ngim N., is a construction worker who earn a small salary to support his family. Mrs. Y. Chan is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare field to cultivate rice. On this farm, she has a small problem because her field is infertile. Therefore she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support her farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Emerson's Group

texts.en:
Emerson L. is from the village of Mangcuram. She is 37 years old. Emerson is the group leader of a twenty-one-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Emerson L..

Emerson is single. To make a living, Emerson owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Emerson has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $175 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Emerson joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emerson is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisher folks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Emily's Group

texts.en:
Emily B. is from the village of Caraniogan. She is 48 years old. Emily is the group leader of a nine-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Emely B.'s Group.

Emily is married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Emily owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Emily has been engaged in her business for over twenty-five years and earns approximately $153 a month from these activities.

In 2006, Emily joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emily has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Emily is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 10th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to further improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Anita's Group

texts.en:
Anita G. is from the village of Bagong Tanza. She is 43 years old. Anita is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Anita G.'s Group.

Anita is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Anita owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Anita has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately $327 a month from these activities.

In 2007, Anita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Anita is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 8th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to further improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
Olivia L. is from the village of Brgy. Lactawan, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 44 years old. Olivia is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Olivia owns and operates a business, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Olivia has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately $150 a month from these activities.

In 2006, Olivia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Olivia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Olivia is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 9th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Gemma is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

loans.name: Mom's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom T. is 48 years old and the village bank president for a 14-person group loan. The members of this loan, offered by Kiva partner AMK, are located in Phdau Tboung village in Takeo province. With their loans, they hope to increase their incomes and improve the living conditions of their families. 
Mrs. Mom T. is a silk weaver who earns a small income to support her family. In order to expand her business and increase her income, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy more silk. This will help improve her family's standard of living. Her husband, Mr. Thy S., is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. The couple has eight children, two of whom are silk weavers and support their mother's weaving business, another is a taxi driver, two are laborers for silk weavers, while the other three attend the local school. All the members of this group loan are shown in the photograph, but one of them is hidden from view.

loans.use: To buy more silk

loans.name: Choung Svay Group

texts.en:
Mr. Choung S. is the village bank president for a group loan consisting of 16 people located in Phdau Tboung village in Takeo province. The members of this group will use their loans to purchase supplies, equipment and other items for different purposes.
Mr. Choung S. is 61 years old, a widower, and has two children, one of whom is a construction worker while the other is a laborer in the silk-weaving industry.  He is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare field to cultivate rice. He is now requesting 400,000 KHR  from Kiva partner, AMK, to purchase fertilizer to support his dry farming. All the members are shown in the photograph but some of them are hidden from view.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Arcelita

texts.en:
Arcelita M. is from the village of Owaon. She is 62 years old, married, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Arcelita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Arcelita has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2006, Arcelita joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to expand shelter for her livestock. Arcelita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This loan will be her fifth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.name: Dalin

texts.en:
Mrs. Dalin N. is 33 years old and is a villager who lives in Chheu Teal Phluoh village in Takeo province. She is farmer who own a 2.5-hectare (6.25-acre) field on which she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Vanna Re, is a duck breeder who is able to earn a small income to support his family. He is shown on the right in the photo.

Aside from farming, Mrs. Dalin N. also raises pigs. She is now requesting 2,000,000 Riels from AMK to buy ten piglets to raise and the rest of the loan she will use to buy pesticide to support her farm crop.

This couple has two children, one of whom is attending in the public school while the youngest one is 3 years old.

loans.use: To buy ten piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhem N. is a 41-year-old married woman who lives in Pongro village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Dieng Long, are farmers who own a 3-hectare (7.5-acre) field on which they cultivate rice.

In her farming, Mrs. Nhem N. does not have enough money to support her field. Thus she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support her crop.

Aside from farming her husband is also a duck breeder who is able to make a small income to support the family. This couple has five children between the ages of 1 and 17. Three of their children are currently in school and help their parents in this business. Her husband is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support her rice field

loans.name: Hakimali

texts.ru: Рахматов Хакимали проживает в районе Хуросон. Возраст, 54 года. Женат, имеет 5 детей. У него средне- специальное образование по професси "Повар". Работает на рынке в своем районе. Имеет небольшую столовую. Работа приност доход, это дает возможность обеспечивать семью. Ему необходимо взять в аренду новое помещение и закупить муки. Поэтому он берет кредит. Это пожет ему улучшить качество обслуживания и сахранить цены на предлагаемую продукцию, так как цены на сырье растут.
texts.en:
Hakimali R. lives in the Khuroson District of Tajikistan. He is 54 years old and married with five children. He has vocational training as a cook. He works in a market in his neighborhood where he has a small dining hall. This work brings in the income which enables him to provide for his family. Hakimali needs to rent a new building and purchase flour; therefore, he is requesting a loan. This will help him improve the quality of his services and maintain production levels as the cost of raw materials rises.

Translated from Russian by Amanda Ross, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Rent additional space and purchase flour

loans.name: Roem

texts.en:
Mrs. Roem T. is a villager who lives in Chuos village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Sorn Sann, are farmers who own a piece of land on which they cultivate rice.

Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income than needed to support their family living. Thus, Mrs. Roem T. decided to start a new business raising pigs.

Mrs. Roem T. is now requesting KHR 2,000,000 from AMK to buy fifteen piglets, pig food and to build a pigpen. With the loan she hopes to increase her income and improve her family too.

Mrs. Roem T. is 31 years old and the mother of four children who all are students in the local school. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fifteen piglets, pig food and to build a pigpen

loans.name: Sony

texts.en:
Mrs. Sony B. is 40 years old and is a villager who lives in Chuos village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Sao Sam, is a construction worker who is able to earn a small salary to support his family. Her husband is shown on the left in the photo.

Aside from farming, Mrs. Sony B. raises pigs at her house. Since her business is going well she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for 2,000,000 Riels from AMK to buy twenty more piglets to enlarge her business. With this loan she hopes to increase her income to improve her family living.

This couple has three children who are all students in the public school.

loans.use: To buy twenty more piglets

loans.name: Voeurn

texts.en:

Aside from farming, Mrs. Voeurn P. is a grocery seller where she can make a small income to support her family.  

Mrs. Voeurn P. now is requesting 2,000,000 Riels from AMK to buy groceries to enlarge her business.   She hopes to earn additional revenue so she can improve the living conditions of her household. 

Mrs. Voeurn P. is a mother of three children; one of them is a seamstress in the garment factory while the other two are students in the local school. Her husband is also in the picture.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Morgana

texts.en:
Morgana Q. is a loving mother to her four children. She is married to her supportive spouse, Simeon, a tricycle (three-wheeled transport) driver, and lives in the coastal province of Teresa, Rizal. She and her husband have been running a general store for almost 8 years. Despite many challenges in their life, they never give up fighting against poverty.

Over the course of her membership in ASHI, Morgana has shown very good performance as a member, and she is trusted by ASHI for her solid record. Aside from maintaining an excellent performance in repayment, business, and attendance in ASHI, Morgana has also cared for the needs of her children at home and in school.

She plans to utilize this loan of Php 20,000 to expand and to support her general store as their primary source of daily income. This loan will be used as additional working capital to pay for groceries for her general store, for inventory such as school supplies, sacks of rice, canned goods, and other groceries.

Morgana hopes the loans from ASHI, KIVA's field partner, will support the education of all her children. Morgana also dreams of a growing business, of building their own house, having a good life and a happy family as well. She believes that her business will help her family to rise up and fight against poverty, as well as providing for the educational needs of her children. She is very grateful to ASHI and KIVA for the continuous love and support of her dreams.

About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the poorest of the poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

Bengina I. is married with two sons and three daughters.  As a busy entrepreneur, she has been making and selling doormats for almost three years. Building her business, Maxima would like to receive a loan amounting 20,000 PHP to increase the inventory of goods sold in her doormat-making business.  She is planning to purchase additional products such as cotton and other supplies.  Maxima believes that offering a wide assortment of doormat products to customers will increase their daily income and maintain customer loyalty in the community.

A committed member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, since 2008 Bengina has been model member, demonstrating regular attendance at weekly meetings and steady repayments on previous loans.

Her dreams are to provide a better future for her family, sustain the profitability of her business, and start a savings account for her children and support them while they finish their studies until they complete college.  Through hard work and determination, Bengina is focused on improving her quality of life through her entrepreneurial initiatives and with support from ASHI and Kiva lenders.

texts.en:
Paz S. is from the village of Mialen, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 61 years old. Paz is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Paz owns & operates transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating motor transport services. Paz has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Paz joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Paz has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from GDMPC. Paz is requesting a new loan of 7,545 PHP which will be used to repair her existing vehicle for better service. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Paz from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair her existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en:
Sharon G. is 40 years old, single, and lives in Morong, an attractive province of Rizal. Reaching an older age, she is working hard on her own. She is grateful that there is an ASHI center in her village that offers her inspiration in life and group support to achieve her dreams.

In 2005, she joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap Inc.) a microfinance institution and KIVA field partner in the Philippines. Sharon operates a RTW (ready-to-wear-clothes) business. She has been in business for more than six years. She believes that her proposed loan of 20,000 PHP will contribute to the sustained growth of her business. She will use all of the loan funds to pay for blouses, skinny jeans, t-shirts, polo shirts, slippers, sandals, and other inventory for her business.  

Sharon is a positive and optimistic woman who knows that she will overcome all challenges and achieve her dreams. She is still dreaming about having an expanding business to save money for her future.

About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the poorest of the poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To pay for blouses, skinny jeans, t-shirts, polo shirts, slippers, sandals, and other inventory

loans.name: Renenaldo

texts.en:
Renenaldo S. is from the town of Alicia, Isabela. He is 36 years old. Renenaldo is married and has two infant children. To make a living, Renenaldo owns and operates a business making and selling food like fish balls and other dimsums (delicacies) to the local community. Renenaldo has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately $113 a month from these activities.

In 2010, Renenaldo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Renenaldo is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products he sells. This will be his 1st loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products he sells

loans.name: Safina Group

texts.en:
Asha N., age 33, is single with two children aged 4 and 2 years. She has a beauty salon which she started in 2000. She opens her salon from 8 am to 9 pm daily and she is able to make  a monthly profit of about  US$ 148 .

This will be Asha’s fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy salon equipment and she has paid back the loan successfully. She hopes for a new loan to further improve  her salon inventory.

Asha will share this loan with her subgroup, Safina Group, which totals 7 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Asha is second from the left behind, in a blue dress.

loans.use: To buy more salon equipment

loans.name: Ry

texts.en:
Mr. Ry K. is a 30-year-old clothing merchant. He also leaves home to sell clothing in bulk for a few days or a week in provinces around Cambodia. This action is the main point of making a profit in order to help be responsible for his family. 

Ry K. is married with two school-aged kids, who are dependent on their parents. His wife weaves cotton hats and sells them in bulk to middlemen who then take them to resell at the market. 

Ry K. is running his clothing enterprise very well. Recently he got purchase orders from his customers but his products are not adequate to serve them, so he is applying for a loan to buy clothes in order to satisfy his customer’s needs. (Ry K. was not available on that day so his wife is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To buy clothes in order to satisfy his customers' needs

loans.name: Amparo

texts.en:
Amparo A. is a married woman who supports her family with her general store and rice mill businesses. She lives in Brgy. Puey, Sagay City, Negros Occidental with her husband and their child.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard at her rice mill and general store businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000.

Amparo is now borrowing Php 15,000 so that she can buy additional equipment for the operation of the rice mill and for the general store. This will be her 9th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 10,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Amparo aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional equipment for rice mill and additional capital for her general store

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena A. is a married woman who supports her family by her food and fish vending business. She lives in Brgy Tamlang, Escalante City, Negros Occidental with her husband and their three adult children.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her food and fish vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 8,000.

Elena is now borrowing Php 14,000 so that she can expand her food and fish vending business. This will be her 11th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 14,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Elena aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira M. is a 50-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy Alimango, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by running her general store which has been in operation for over 5 years.

Elvira’s 50-year-old husband, Henrico, is a tricycad driver.  They have 4 children aged between 12 – 26 years old with some of them currently going to school and helping out in the business as part of their daily chores.

Elvira joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by running the general store. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 3,000 from her business activities.

Elvira is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 19,000 was used for the operations of her general store which had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 10th loan the amount of Php 17,000, which she also intends to use on her general store. Elvira is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Artak

texts.en:
Artak B. is 37 years old and lives in Ijevan city. He is married and has two children: a son and a daughter. Artak graduated from Ijevan Technological College.

Artak has a lot of experience in auto repairing and in 2007 he organized his own auto repairing business in his own place. He says that his business is very difficult but he is appreciated for his work. With the profit from his auto repairing service Artak solves all his family’s needs.

Artak asks for a 1,000,000 AMD loan to buy a welding set, machine oil and paints for his business.

loans.use: To buy a welding set, machine oil and paints for his business

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria A. is a 52-year-old married woman who lives in Jingjang Village, Barangay Alimango, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by fishing and selling fish. Gloria’s 48-year-old husband, Ronie, works in a sugarcane plantation. They have seven children, 14 to 32 years old, with some of them having their own families while the others are currently going to school and help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores. Gloria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in fishing and selling fish in her local community. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 3,000. Gloria is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 15,000 was used to fund operations of her fishing and fish-selling and had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 15,000 as her 9th loan, which she intends to use as an additional working capital and to buy fishing nets. Gloria is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital and to buy fishing nets

loans.name: Ie

texts.en:
Mrs. Ie S., 58 years old, is a good homemaker who cooks tasty meals and cares for her children. She has six children: four are married and have already started new homes while the remaining two are single. Most of the children are employed at different jobs. They sometimes provide their income to help contribute to the family. Ie S. was not available when the photo taken so her husband is shown instead.

To earn a living, Ie S. and her husband cultivate crops which they sell to a buyer when the crops mature. Due to the fact that the farm is far from the watering system, Ie S. is hardly able to irrigate her crops. Thus, she has asked for a loan to buy an irrigation pump for her crops.

loans.use: To buy an irrigatation pump for her crops

loans.name: Guerlita

texts.en: Fifty-nine-year-old Guerlita R. is a married woman who has supported her family with her general store and food-vending business for over twenty years. She lives with her her husband, Rodolfo, and their two adult children at Purok Mainawaon, Barangay Tabot-ao, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. Guerlita has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and food-vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 30,000. Guerlita is now borrowing Php 12,000 so that she can expand her general store and food-vending businesses. This will be her 9th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 7,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Guerlita aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en: Jenny G. is a 28-year-old married woman who lives in Beatingo, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living with her general store. Jennie’s husband, Francis, works as a caretaker of the fish ponds. They have two children, 6 and 9 years old, who are currently going to school while helping their parents in the business as part of their daily chores. Jenny joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in her general store. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 4,000. Jenny is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 5,000 was used to fund the operations of her general store and had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 9,000 for her 4th loan, which she intends to use for her general store. Jenny is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. loans.use: To use as additional working capital

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria A. is a married woman who supports her family with her general store and pig-fattening businesses. She lives in Cabulakan, Barangay Maguiling, Sagay City, Negros Occidental, with her husband and their five adult children. Maria has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1997 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and pig fattening businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 15,000. Maria is now borrowing Php 14,000 so that she can expand her general store and pig-fattening businesses. This will be her 8th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHp 12,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Maria aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. loans.use: To buy an additional piglet and to use as additional capital for her general store

loans.name: Marites

texts.en: Forty-one-year-old Marites M. is a married woman who supports her family with her general store and her fishing business. She lives in Purok Paglaum, Barangay Taba-ao, Sagay City, Negros Occidental, with her husband and their two children who are currently going to school. Marites has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and fishing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 22,000. Marites is now borrowing Php 14,000 so that she can expand her general store. This will be her 9th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 14,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Marites aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: Thirty-eight-year-old Nancy T. is a married woman who helps support her family with her general store business. She lives in Cogon 1, Barangay Alimango, Escalante City, Negros Occidental, with her husband, Roberto, who is a carpenter, and their two children, 16 and 19 years old, who are currently going to school. Nancy has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2001 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 4,000. Nancy is now borrowing Php 9,000 so that she can buy additional items for her general store. This will be her 8th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 9,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Nancy aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. loans.name: Say

texts.en:
Mrs. N., a 50-year-old married mother, lives with her husband and children in a wooden house located in a commune in the province of Siem Reap. There, she earns a living producing mats for sale. The raw material she uses to weave mats is from palm leaves and thatch.

In addition, her husband earns a daily income by fishing in and around Tunle Sap. Fishing is very profitable for the family. However, recently, the quantity of fish is decreasing due to some of his equipment being broken. Because of this, N. is asking for a loan to buy more fishing equipment.

The couple has seven children: three are married and four are single.

loans.use: To buy more fishing equipment for her husband

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en: Forty-seven-year-old Nenita D. is a married woman who supports her family with her general store which has been in operation for the past twenty-two years. She lives in Purok Maghirupay, Central Lopez, Sagay City, Negros Occidental, with her 51-year-old husband, Roberto, who is a fish vendor. They have five children who are between 6 and 22 years old with two of them currently going to school. Nenita has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 15,000. Nenita is now borrowing Php 19,500 so that she can expand her general store business. This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 19,500, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Nenita aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable).
