They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her general store

loans.name: Kassem

texts.en:
Kassem has owned a car repair shop in his village for the past 8 years. He's 30 years old, single and lives with his mother, and he's the only provider for her. He's specialized in repairing the bodies of cars and he's very talented at his job. He's well-known in the whole region. 

Today, Kassem is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy more tools and spare parts and enlarge his shop to meet the requirements of his clients and make a good income for his family.

loans.use: To buy more tools and spare parts.

loans.name: Sokhon

texts.en:
Mr. Sokhon K. is 43 years old and he is a villager who lives in Srae Vong village in TaK. province. He is a farmer who owns a 2 hectare field where he cultivates rice. His wife is a grocery seller and also a pig breeder, from which she can earn a small income to support her family.

Mr. Sokhon K. is now requesting 2,000,000 Riels from AMK to buy piglets, pig food, and the rest of the loan he will use to purchase supplies to support his farming activities. This couple has five children, one of whom is seamstress in the garment factory, another one is a laborer in Malaysia, while the other three are students in the local school and also help their parents' businesses. His wife is on the left of the picture.

loans.use: To buy piglets, pig food, and farming supplies.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: So

texts.en: Mrs. So R. owns a machine that she uses to squeeze sugar cane juice, which she sells to the people for a profit. From this business she earns approximately $1.50 a day, which she uses to solve the family’s financial problems. She has a life partner in her husband (he appears in the photo), who owns a few pieces of equipment to provide a vehicle repair service, earning $10 each day. So R.’s husband requires more vehicle repair equipment to perform a good service, but he doesn’t have cash yet. Therefore, So R. is requesting a loan to buy the required articles. The couple are the parents of six children.

loans.use: To buy vehicle repair equipment.

loans.name: Thach

texts.en: Mrs. Thach E. is 56 years old and a villager who lives in Chen village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Thoe Non, is a Khmer noodle seller and also supports his wife's farming. In order to support her husband's business, Mrs. Thach E. decided to ask for a loan to purchase a motorbike for her husband's transportation to resell the Khmer noodles door-to-door. This couple has four children, one of whom is seamstress in the garment factory, while the other three are farmers and also support their parent's business. Her husband is on the right of the picture.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Mr. Kong R., 26, owns an old vehicle that he uses to provide a taxi service for income. Additionally, he has a small farm where he raises ducks and pigs to produce eggs for sale. His wife is pictured above, who assists him in breeding animals and is also a good homemaker for the family. They both help each other to earn money in order to feed two kids who are enrolled in the secondary school. Kong R. will use his first loan to accrue a larger amount of pigs and ducks to breed.

loans.use: To accrue a larger amount of pigs and ducks to breed.

loans.name: Khoeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Khoeurn S. is from the village of Srae Boeng, Takeo province. She is a 48 year old married woman with a child who is a student in the local school.

Mrs. Khoeurn S. is a farmer who owns a piece of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Thoch Chhaeng, owns a wedding hall that he rents out. Now her husband wants to purchase an electric machine and 3 speakers. Thus, Khoeurn S. decided to ask for a loan from AMK to support her husband's business. This loan she hopes will increase her income and improve her family's living too. Her husband is on the right of the picture.

loans.use: To purchase an electric machine and 3 speakers.

loans.name: Pelita

texts.en:
Pelita G. is a married woman who has supported her family from her denture business for over 17 years. She lives in Prk Jison, Pob 2, Sagay City, Negros Occidental, with her husband Maximo, 42 years old, who has a buy and sell business of animals. They have 5 children between 9 and 20 years old, who are currently at school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since March  2001, and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her denture business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000.

Pelita is now borrowing PHP 20,000 so that she can buy additional materials for the business. This will be her 19th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP18,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Pelita aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy additional materials for her denture business.

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en:
Oyun is 50 years old and lives with her son in Tuv province, Mongolia. She and her son live together in their own apartment. Oyun's son goes to a local secondary school. They  have been living in their current home for 13 years. Since 2006, Oyun has run a children's play center with many kinds of toys. Originally, Oyun was a kindergarten teacher between 1982 and 2006. She has been renting space for the business, and plans to purchase her own workplace in the future. With her business profits, Oyun has been providing for her family's expenses.

Oyun is a very hard working and honest person. She is focused on the future and says, “I would like to create my own private kindergarten in the future. My son will graduate from secondary school this year, and I have to be financially ready to pay for my son's university tuition fees. I want my children to get a good education.” Oyun is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase a variety of products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more toys.

loans.name: Ing

texts.en: The woman in the photo is Mrs. Ing S., age 55, who lives in the Province of Siem Reap in Cambodia, where she earns a living raising pigs in a stall behind her house. Since 1985, she has run this business and it has provided her with income to attain her standard of living. She is married with six children: two are married living separately and four are single. Her husband helps feed the family by working in construction. In order to earn extra income, Ing S. will be using the loan to buy more pig feed and piglets to raise.

loans.use: To buy more pig feed and piglets to raise.

loans.name: Lon

texts.en: Mrs. Lon N. is 59 years old and a villager who lives in Srae Boeng village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns an 8 hectare field to cultivate rice and owns a plowing machine and a water pump machine to support her farming. In this farming, she now faces a problem because she does not have enough money to support her farming. Thus she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide to support her farming and the rest of the loan she will use to repair her plowing machine and water pump machine. Mrs. Lon N. is a widow with a child who is a students and also supports the mother's farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide, and to repair her plowing and water pump machines.

loans.name: Gbemileke

texts.en: Gbemileke sells motor spare parts at retail prices to his customers. He has been in this business for a long time. He needs the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more motor spare parts to sell. He is a hard working man. He is 36 years old and married with 2 children. His children attend school and this gives him joy. He lives in Oyo state, Nigeria, and says thanks to all Kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more motor parts to sell.

loans.name: Krisanto

texts.en:
Krisanto D. is from the village of Calabayan Minanga, Angadanan, Isabela. He is 30 years old and married. To make a living, Krisanto owns and operates a service-based business, providing internet services in the local community. He is just starting this business.

In 2010, Krisanto joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional equipment. This will be his 1st loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to further expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional equipment

loans.name: Lieb

texts.en: Mrs. Lieb N. is 47 years old and a villager who lives in Srae Boeng village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 6-hectare field to cultivate rice and owns a water pump machine to pump the water to support her crop. In order to further support her crops, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide, and the rest of the loan she will use to repair her water pump machine. Mrs. Lieb N. is a widow with two children, one of whom is a laborer while the other one is a student.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide and repair her water pump machine.

loans.name: Rima

texts.en:
Rima is a 38 year old single woman who lives with her parents and 2 siblings. She really likes arts and crafts works and she’s very artistic in this area. That’s the reason why in 2008, she opened her own handicrafts, chocolates, accessories, and gadgets shop to begin a new career and earn income. She offers beauty products to her clients and during this short period she has gained a good reputation in the whole region. 

Today, Rima is requesting to borrow $600 to buy artisanA. supplies and accessories for her shop, so that she can take more orders.

loans.use: To buy artisanal supplies and accessories.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Mr. Sam P. is married, but his wife died of senility years ago. He now takes care of a teenage child who is no longer in school and works raising pigs from home. Sam P. is aged 57 and earns a living by fishing along the Tunle Sap River. He has operated in this sector since 2000 and is able to make $3 per day. Sam P. has been planning to invest in the pig trade for a year, but has been unable to due to lack of capital. He is therefore looking for a Kiva loan to be used to buy piglets to begin breeding.

loans.use: To buy piglets to begin breeding.

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en: Mrs. Soeun S. is a 57 year old married woman who lives in Lieb village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Teav S., are farmers who own a 2-hectare field to cultivate rice. In order to support the farming, Mrs. Soeun S. decided to ask for a loan to purchase a water pump machine. Aside from being a farmer, her husband is collects palm juice and is also a fisherman, which earns him a small income to support his family's living. This couple has two children who are farmers and support their parent's farming.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump machine.

loans.name: Nourn

texts.en:
Mrs. Nourn P. is a villager who lives in Phngeas village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Trork Ou, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from being a farmer, her husband sells fish, and owns a motorbike to transport the fish to sell and earn a living. Since her husband's business is doing well, she wants to expand it.
 
Mrs. Nourn P. is now requesting 2,000,000 Riels from AMK to buy more fish to resell. With this loan she hopes to earn additional income, so she can improve the living conditions of her family. Mrs. Nourn P. is a mother of three children, one of whom supports the parent's businesses, another one is a student in the local school, while the youngest one is 4 years old.

loans.use: To buy more fish.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Vai

texts.en: Mr. Vai V. is a 54 year old farmer who lives in Siem Reap Province. Vai V. is married to Sorm Khy, age 51. This couple, who work together in the farming business, has given birth to seven children: four of the children are married and working and three are single. Due to the coming farming season, Vai V. wants to grow a great amount of crops in order to sell them when they have matured. As he lacks money to make that possible, Vai V. has decided to request a loan from Kiva. Vai V. will use these funds to buy fertilizers and vegetable seeds to plant.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and vegetable seeds to plant.

loans.name: Saron

texts.en: Mrs. SarO. O. is a 29 year old married woman who lives in Phngeas village in Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who own a 2-hectare field where they cultivate rice. In this dry farming seasO. they do not have enough money to support their field. Thus, Mrs. SarO. O. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer, pesticide, and the rest of the loan she will use to buy duck feed to support her husband's duck breeding, because aside from farming, her husband is a duck breeder. This couple has three children, one of whom is attending the local school, while the other two are too young to study or work. Her husband is O. the left of the picture.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, pesticide, and duck feed.

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en: Jacob is married without children. He is 38 years old and his wife also works to support their home. He is a hard working and affectionate person. He sells bags of poultry feed at retail prices. His customers are usually friends and residents. He lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. He has been in this business for 5 years. Jacob is requesting a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more bags of poultry feed to sell. Jacob says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of poultry feed to sell.

loans.name: Sam Ol

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam Ol S. is 34 years old and a villager who lives in Damnak village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Rattana Sen, is a taxi driver who earns a small income to support his family.

Mrs. Sam Ol S. is now requesting 2,000,000 Riels from AMK to purchase a cow for cow breeding, and the rest of the loan she will use to purchase two wheels for her husband's car. This couple has three children:  two of them are students in the local school, while the youngest one stays at home.

loans.use: To purchase a cow.

loans.name: Pe

texts.en:
Pe C. is a 47-year-old farmer and father. He was blessed with five kids, two of whom are married while the other three are single. One of his sons is a taxi driver. His wife, Chean Orn, is 45 and works in the farming business. 

Pe C. inherited the farmland where he and his wife grow different kinds of crops from his grandmother. In additional, he breeds a few pigs in his pigpen. 

Pe C. is taking out his loan to mend and refurbish his existing motorcycle which is very old and broken down.

loans.use: To mend and refurbish his existing motorcycle

loans.name: Leakhena

texts.en:
Mrs. Leakhena T., age 33, and her husband, Mr. Yeun Yem, age 35, have been married since 1998 and have two daughters. One of them attends school and other one is still young. The family lives in a small village of National Road Number 2 about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Leakhena has been selling vegetables for two months. She buys them from her village and transports them to sell in Takhmao market about 10 kilometers from her house. Her husband has been a traditional musician for five years as well.  

Leakhena is requesting a loan of US$ 150 to purchase a trailer to carry the vegetables for resale.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to carry her vegetables for resale

loans.name: Phat

texts.en: Mr. Phat T. is 27 years old and he lives in Roluos village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice on. His wife, Mrs. Nieng Seang, is a Khmer cheese maker so she can earn a small income to help support her family. Since his wife's business is going well, he wants to expand it. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to purchase more  Khmer cheese  (4 tons) to sell. With this loan, he hopes to increase their income to improve his family's living conditions. This couple has a child who is too young to study or work. His wife is also in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase more  Khmer cheese (4 tons)

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita L. is 44 years old and married with four children. The eldest is a college graduate, two children are in high school and one is attending elementary school.  Juanita lives with her family in the province of Rizal in the Philippines.  Her husband works long hours as a fisherman to support the family.  To supply additional income, Juanita wants to expand the family fishing business through additional working capital. 

Juanita would like to receive a loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase an inventory of fish nets, rope, bamboo, fingerlings (small fish), and additional raw materials.  With additional equipment, Juanita believes that her fish supply will increase, bringing higher revenue.

Over the course of her membership since 2008, Juanita has achieved strong performance with regular attendance at center meetings and steady repayments.  Juanita is thankful for access to capital and loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams.  With the support of ASHI and Kiva, she is hopeful that their expanded business will continue to flourish, to improve the family’s quality of life, and fund all of her children’s expenses in school until college education.

About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the poorest of the poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To purchase inventory of fish nets, rope, bamboo, fingerlings (small fish), and additional raw materials

loans.name: Melina

texts.en:
Melina is a married mother of three children.  Her husband, Romeo is a boat driver in the community while she manages her own fish business to supply additional income for the family.   Melina is a hard-working entrepreneur who has been in business for almost two years.  

Melina would like to receive a loan amounting 20,000 PHP to reconstruct her fishing business as it was partially destroyed by Hurricane Ondoy last year. The loan funds will be used as working capital for her fish business to fund raw materials like a fish net, bamboo, rope, fingerlings (small fish), as well as labor costs.  A proud member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, since 2006 Melina has been a dedicated member demonstrating regular attendance to weekly meetings and steady repayments on previous loans.

Her long-term goal is to renovate her home.  Also, she hopes the profits from her business will fund continued education for all three children.  With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, she is determined to achieve business success to build more long-term financial security for herself and her family.

About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the poorest of the poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To fund raw materials like a fish net, bamboo, rope, fingerlings (small fish), as well as labor costs

loans.name: Mbande Group

texts.en:
Agness Mathew, age 35, is married and has four children ages 13, 11, 8, and 6.  She has been selling rice and wheat flour at wholesale prices, for two years now.  She opens her shop from 7 am to 6 pm daily and has been able to make a monthly profit of  around  US$ 150.

This will be Agnes’s 1st 'motisha' loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She hopes to obtain a loan to increase her inventory of rice and wheat flour.
	
Agness will share this loan with her loan group, which totals 9 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.  In the picture,  Agness is  3rd from left.

loans.use: To buy more rice and wheat flour

loans.name: Fatimo

texts.en:
Fatimo runs a barbering salon with a viewing center where people gather to watch football matches in same arena. She also sells drinks. She buys drinks in bulk and sells them retail and has been in this business since 2005.

Fatimo is 51 years old, married, and has six children. With the business she is able to assist her husband in supporting the household. She further said they intend to renovate their building, which forms part of where she runs her business, though her profit.

Fatimo is requesting the loan amount of NGN 120,000 to buy more drinks to sell. She expresses her appreciation to all lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mrs. Mao K., 41, is a widow and the mother of two children, both of whom are students and dependent on her income. She currently lives with her older mother who stays at home to do housework or assists her in the business. 

To earn their living, Mao K. always buys farming produce (beans and rice) in bulk from the farmers who bring their produce to sell directly to her house. Also, she stores them in her house for a while before selling, thus gaining profit. Mao K. is looking for assistance to increase the financial capital of her enterprise.

loans.use: To increase the financial capital of her enterprise

loans.name: Modou Bousso

texts.fr:
Monsieur Modou Bousso K. sollicite un prêt de 150 000 FCFA  pour d’une part,  se payer un équipement meubles  et d’autres part,  investir dans une  activité d’aviculture. Nouvellement marié, Monsieur Modou Bousso K. compte acheter un équipementde meubles. Cet achat constitue un investissement nécessaire besoin pour sa chambre. 
Vivant  à la maison familiale, il participe pour la gestion collective des besoins quotidiens de la maison.  Ainsi pour accroitre le revenu familial, il compte également si possible avec le reste de l’argent financer son jeune frère qui connait bien l’aviculture. L’impact du crédit pour cet enseignant âgé de 29 ans c’est aussi de créer un emploi pour son jeune frère, équiper sa chambre et diversifier les ressources financières.
texts.en:
Mr. Modou Bousso K. is applying for a loan of 150,000 FCFA, which is partly to pay for a piece of furniture and partly to invest in a poultry farming business. Newly wed, Mr. Modou Bousso K. is planning to buy a piece of furniture. This is a necessary investment for his bedroom. Since he lives in the family home, he participates in the collective management of the daily needs of the household. Thus, in order to increase the family's revenues, he is equally planning to use the rest of the money, if possible, to finance his young brother who is very familiar with the poultry farming business. The impact of the loan for this 29-year old teacher will thus be to create a job for his young brother, to furnish his bedroom and diversify his financial resources.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To acquire furniture and launch a business for his brother

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita C. is a married woman who supports her family by her fishing and fish vending business. She lives in Cogon 2, Brgy Alimango, Escalante City, Negros Occidental with her 55-year-old husband, Eddie, who is a fisherman.  They have 6 children between the ages of 13 to 23 years old.

Rosita has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing and fish vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 3,000.

Rosita is now borrowing Php 11,000 so that she can continue her fishing and fish vending business. This will be her 9th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 11,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Rosita aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Sherifat

texts.en:
Sherifat sells groceries – washing soap, milk, diapers, juice, and drinks. She is six years in the business. She works hard and ensures that customers’ needs are met. She wants to expand her business and hopes for a bigger shop in future. 

Sherifat is asking for loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell and make more profit. 

Sherifat is 47 years old, married with two children; they are aged 8 and 25 years old. Being a mother and a wife, she is happy playing some vital roles in the family, and this is because she is financially empowered via her business. She thanks all Kiva lenders and LAPO Microfinance for their support

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Adela

texts.en:
Adela B. is a 39-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy Malabugas, Pasil, Bayawan City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living through her pig-fattening and net-working business.

Adela’s husband, Albeto, is a fisherman.  They have 3 children from 18 to 22 years old.  They are currently helping their father with the fishing.

Adela joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in the pig-fattening and net-working businesses. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 4,800 from her business activities.

Adela is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 15,000 was used to fund operations for her pig-fattening, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing, for her 13th loan, the amount of Php 15,000, which she intends to use on her pig-fattening and net-working business. Adela is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Kak

texts.en:
Mrs. Kak S. is 41-year-old farmer. She also goes to where there is a lot of fruit sold in bulk in order to buy fruit and she then brings it to sell retail at the market for extra income. She has a life partner in her husband who is a bicycle repairman. This couple have been married for many years and they have five teenage children. Two of the children are helping the parents' business and two attend school. 

Kak S. will use her first loan to buy more bicycle accessories to supply her husband’s business. Any remaining money from the loan will be used to buy a pig to raise.

loans.use: To buy more bicycle accessories

loans.name: Ny

texts.en:
Mrs. Ny K. (pictured here), age 57, and her husband, Mr. Meng Pen, age 55, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1979 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. One of them is married and lives outside the family home and two have full-time employment in Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Ny K. has been a silk weaver since she was 16 years old, a skill she learned form her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village who then in turn brings them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband has been a farmer for 24 years. 

Ny is requesting a loan in the amount of $400 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en:
Rosana  L. is a 42-year-old married  woman who lives in Brgy San Francisco, Sta Catalina, Negros Oriental with her 44-year-old husband, Eduardo, who works as a carpenter. They have three children between the ages of 16 – 26 years old with one helping out in the business while the other two are currently attending school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1993 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing and food vending in a school, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 15,000.

Rosana is now borrowing Php 15,000 so that she can expand her fishing and food vending businesses. This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 19,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Rosana aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta G. is a widow who supports her family through her general store, fish vending and pig fattening businesses. She lives in Sitio Buhian, Brgy. To-oy, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental with her 8 children who are 23 to 39 years old.  Some of her children already have a stable job which is a big help in the family.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, fish vending and pig fattening businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000.

Violeta Gavillanes is now borrowing Php 16,000 so that she can use it as additional working capital for her general store, pig fattening and fish vending businesses. This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 22,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Violeta  aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Kimrong

texts.en:
Mr. Kimrong T., age 43, and his wife, Mrs. Savoeun Kean, age 33, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 2001 and have three children: one son and two daughters. Kimrong is not in the photo, but his wife was available instead. 

Kimrong and his wife have been selling finished silk fabric for two years. They buy it from weavers in their village and transport it to sell in other provinces far way from their home. 

Kimrong wants to expand his business, so he is requesting his first loan in the amount of US$ 500 to purchase more finished silk fabric for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more finished silk fabrics for resale

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mr. Chea T., age 53, is married with six children, two of whom are married and four are attending school. He is a rice cultivator who has a big farmland to plant rice crops on. For extra profit, he also goes to the river where he uses some implements to fish. His wife works breeding animals outside of their home for sale. Usually the couple generate around US$ 6 in profit a day to meet the needs of their family. 

Chea T. is taking out a loan of US$ 600 for his wife to purchase piglets, ducks, and chickens to continue raising. (Chea T. was not available for a photo, so his wife is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To purchase piglets, ducks, and chickens to raise

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose G. is a 82-year-old widowed woman living in the region of Diourbel, Senegal. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" NGASCOP for 13 years and has always paid back her loans on time. Her main activity consists in raising cattle and sheep which she sells at the big market of nearby Bambey. 

With this loan, Rose G. will purchase more sheep and cattle to raise. The revenues generated by her activity allow her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: Puchase of cattle and sheep

loans.name: Armine

texts.en:
Armine G. was born in 1965 and she lives in Jean city. She is married and lives with her husband, her son, daughter-in-law, and her newborn grandchild. 

Armine has been engaged in trading business for a long time and in 2002, she organized her own food trading business. Armine’s son and her husband help her to manage this shop. Armine’s food shop is located in the City Market Centre and her shop is open twenty-four hours a day.

With the profits from her business, Armine provides her family's needs, makes major repairs of her apartment, and organized her son’s wedding.

Armine needs a 1.000.000 AMD loan to increase the goods assortment of her shop: sausages, canned goods, sugar, butter and some household goods.

loans.use: To increase the goods assortment of her shop

loans.name: Eda

texts.en:
Eda A. is a 51-year-old woman.  She lives in the town of Had. Sara-et, Himamaylan City.  She is married and has two children.  To make a living, Eda owns & operates a business venture. She runs a general store which has been successful so far.  The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community.  She sells small items in single-use packages, soft drinks, and other items.  Eda has been engaged in this business for over 11 years.  From these activities, Eda earns approximately Php 10,000 a month.

In 1999, Eda joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.    She is now requesting a new loan of Php 15,000.  The current loan will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  This will be the 17th loan taken out by the borrower from NWTF.  Eda plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional capital for her 'sari sari' store

loans.name: Josiah

texts.en: Josiah is a good business man and is doing well in his retail charcoal business. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers and hopes to expand it in the future. Josiah is 40 years old and married with three children. He lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. Josiah is requesting a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Mr. Long K., age 35, and his wife, Mrs. Sophak Moung, 36, have been married since 1999 and have four daughters -- all of them in school. They  live along National Road Number Six about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. The photo is of Sophak.

Long has been driving a Tuk Tuk taxi in Phnom Penh for a year. His wife stays at home and does housework. Unhappily, his Tuk Tuk is old and does not work well. This makes it difficult for him because the taxi is his only source of income. This is why Long is requesting his first loan of $1,000 to purchase a new Tuk Tuk to replace the old one.

loans.use: To purchase new Tuk Tuk taxi to replace the old one.

loans.name: Exaltacion

texts.en:
Exaltacion Y. a is a 55-year old married woman who lives in Galicia Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by her general store. Exaltacion’s 64 year old husband, Rogelio, and the adult children help in running the business. 

Exaltacion joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1994 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the family's quality of life. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase the family income from their general store. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 5,000 from her business activities.

Exaltacion is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 17,500 was used to fund operations for her general store and had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 16th cycle loan, the amount of Php 12,000, which she intends to use on the general store. Exaltacion is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine W. Gichehais a 42 year old widow with four children. Three of her children attend school. Catherine has owned a beauty shop where she sells cosmetics and hair products among other products for the last seventeen years. She employs one person.  Being a member of Faulu Kenya, Catherine previously received a loan of Kes.50,000.  Her business has grown from a retail to wholesale business since she became a member of Faulu Kenya.  Now Catherine is requesting a loan of Kes. 75,000  to expand her business by increasing her stock of cosmetics.  Catherine, who describes herself as hardworking and trustworthy, hopes to  become a distributor of cosmetics in the future.

loans.use: To increase her stock of cosmetics

loans.name: Nang

texts.en:
Mrs. Nang S., age 33 and her husband, Mr. Phea So, age 35, have been married since 1999 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of them are in school. Besides  her children, Nang also has her mother living with her. The family lives along National Road Number Six about 10 Kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Nang has been selling groceries for two years, while her husband has been a barber for five years. He drives a motor taxi in as well. Nang is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to repair her grocery store and purchase grocery items for her inventory.

loans.use: To repair her grocery store and buy grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Nzega Group

texts.en:
Mbaya M., age 35, is married with  three  children ages, 14, 10 and 7  years.  He has had a business of selling beer, sodas and water for three years.  He opens his business at 6am to 9pm daily and he is able to earn a monthly profit of about $414.

This will be Mbaya’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loan to buy more stock of his grocery store and he has paid back the loan successfully. He hopes for a new loan to still improve  his stock.

Mbaya will share this loan with his loan group Nzega, comprised of 17 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Mbaya is behind in a pink shirt second from left.

loans.use: To buy more beer,sodas and water

loans.name: Nabil

texts.en:
Nabil is a 60-year-old married man and father of 2 children. He has owned a car painting shop for the past 40 years. Over the years, thanks to his business income, Nabil has been able to meet his family needs and raise his children to become mature and independent. 

Today, Nabil is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a new air compressor needed for his business. This would replace his long used and inefficient one.

loans.use: To purchase a new air compressor

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana O. is a hard working and honest woman. She is married with 5 children and she is 50 years old. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. Juliana sells bags of groundnut (peanuts) and soybeans at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business for long time. Currently her business income is not enough to meet all her family's needs. Juliana is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more bags of groundnut and soybeans to increase her business income.  She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of groundnuts (peanuts) and soybeans to sell

loans.name: Noun

texts.en:
Mrs. Noun H., (pictured in the photograph),  is a 51 year old  widow with seven children: two sons and five daughters. One of them married and lives outside the family home, one is a construction worker, another one is a garment factory worker and the others attend school. They are living along National Road Number One, about thirty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Noun has been a farmer since 1982. She grows rice on her farmland in the village. Noun doesn’t have capital to maintain her farm, so she is requesting a loan in the amount of $500 to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.use: To use for farm supplies

loans.name: Tuyangatane Group

texts.en:
Hamisi N., age 39, is married and has two children ages 5, and 1.  He has had a retail shop  for 5 years and opens his shop from 7am to 9pm daily.  From this business he is able to  earn a monthly profit of about $196.
This will be Hamisi’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He hopes to obtain a loan to increase the stock in his shop.
	
Hamisi will share this loan with his loan group Tuyangatane, which totals 9 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.  In the picture, Hamis is the man in the middle.

loans.use: To buy more stock for his retail shop

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein is a 53-year-old married man with 3 children one of whom is working. The two other children are still going to school. Hussein is the only provider of his family. He has owned a car repair shop since 1990 in his town and he repairs all type of cars. Hussein is well known by a large number of customers due to his long experience in this occupation. 

Hussein is requesting a loan $1,000  to buy a large quantity of car oil to sell to his clients.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of car oil to sell

loans.name: Josphat

texts.en: Josphat A. M. is a 50 year old married father of five children.  He has been operating a taxi business for sixteen years.  He was previously a care-taker in Buruburu Church of God before he ventured into business. He also earns extra income from farming.  Josphat has been an active member of Faulu Kenya and he has previously participated by taking out five loans.  He appreciates that he has been taught by Faulu Kenya how to pay back his loans and to be alert on issues concerning his business.  Josphat has requested a loan of Kes.74,754 to pay school fees for his three children who are still in school. In the future, Josphat hopes to own a plot in Nairobi and to build residential houses.

loans.use: To pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Mr. Soeun C., 49 and his wife, Mrs. Chenda Vann, 43, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1986 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Mrs Chenda Vann is pictured in the photograph. 

Soeun has been a wooden house builder for 3 years, while his wife has been a silk weaver for 10 years. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Soeun does not have enough materials to operate his business, so he is requesting a loan of $1,000 in order to purchase building materials.

loans.use: To buy materials for his wooden house building business.

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en:
Kenneth C. is thirty-eight years old, married to a farmer, and has eight children aged between twenty-four years and six years old. His business is located at Mukumu near Mukumu primary school.  He has been selling salt, sugar, cooking oil, cakes and other items for the last fourteen years to the local people. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge is that there are so many people in the area doing the same kind of business. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

Kenneth is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy sugar, cooking oil and other things to grow his business and later, buy his own plot of land. He is a hard-working and visionary man.

loans.use: Sugar, cooking oil, soft drinks and other things

loans.name: Ruzanna

texts.en:
Ruzanna B. was born in 1960 and lives in Atcharkut village, Ijevan area. She is married and lives with her husband. Ruzanna has a daughter and two sons who are married and live separately from their parents.

For a several years Ruzanna worked as a cook in the village kindergarten. Now she has her own food shop, which is placed by a beautiful river bank and in spring and summer seasons there are a lot of campers.

March is the month for campers' seasonal opening, so Ruzanna needs a 500,000 AMD loan to increase the assortment of her food shop, so as to serve her customers in the best way.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of her food shop

loans.name: Annastasia

texts.en:
Annastasia is a 39-year-old lady who operates a butchery in Komarock area in Nairobi.   Her husband runs a salon.  They are blessed with two children who are in school.  She also runs a salon to earn extra income.  She has been a member of Faulu Kenya and previously took a loan of Kes 40,000.  She plans to buy salon equipment and cosmetics, increase her butchery stock and buy a small fridge.  

As a result, Annastasia has requested a loan in the amount of Kes.74,000.  She hopes to have rental houses in the future.  She dreams of expanding her business into a  wholesale one.

loans.use: Add stock of meat and buy a fridge

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David O. A. is thirty-nine years old. He is married and they have five children between the ages of twelve years and four years old. They hope to give their children good education to university level. His wife helps him in the running of their business. 

Davids business is located at Kakamega in a very busy market. He has been selling doorlocks, padlocks, chains, forks, iron boxes and other items in his hardware store for the last six years. Besides the hardware store, he runs a taxi and he also does farming. His major customers at the hardware store are farmers and shopkeepers. 

David says his major challenge is low sales and the farmers who are not able to pay their debts on time. However, he works very hard from early morning to late evening to ensure that his business is running well. In future, he wishes to buy many vehicles for a transport business. He is very hard-working, ambitious and patient.

loans.use: Chains, doorlocks, padlocks, forks and iron boxes

loans.name: Consolata

texts.en:
Consolata is a 40-year-old married lady with one child.  She runs a cafeteria where she sells doughnuts, chips, tea and milk. She has been running the business for seven years.  

As a member of Faulu Kenya, she has previously taken out two loans worth Kes.110,000.  She has seven employees and she wants to buy them staff uniforms  and renovate her business premise.   Therefore, she has requested Kes.60,000 from Faulu Kenya.  

Consolata hopes to serve many customers so as to increase her income and educate her daughter who is in school. In ten years' time, she hopes to move her business to a spacious environment.

loans.use: Buy uniforms for employees & renovate the business premises

loans.name: Abigail

texts.en:
Abigail O. is married with 4 children and she is 42 years old. She is a friendly and hard-working mother. She sells mouth-watering Nigerian cooked foods like rice and beans. She is well known in her community and this gives her joy because people patronize her cooked foods. She hopes to add more new recipes in her food to attract and retain more customers. She has been in this business for a long time. 

Abigail is requesting the loan amount of  NGN 50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and to sell

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
B. Irina is 37 years old. She is married and the loving mother of two children. Irina owns a successful clothing sales business at the market of Dushanbe, Tajikistan. She has been doing this business for about 10 years. Her business has benefited from a good sales location and constant demand for her products. 

Irina tries to offer good prices to her customers while still making a profit. She has requested a loan of 1500 USD to increase her product inventory. By purchasing additional inventory, Irina will be better prepared to meet increased demand and earn a good income. We believe her persevering work and natural liveliness will help her continue to succeed in her trade and repay this loan on time.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Increasing working capital with the purpose of growing her business

loans.name: Mavlyuda

texts.en:
T. Mavlyuda is a widowed mother of two children. Eight years ago, Mavlyuda started her clothing business. Experienced and talented in the business, Mavlyuda has expanded her business into a successful trade, supporting her family. 

Throughout the last five years, IMON has provided ongoing assistance to Mavlyuda’s business through microfinance loans. Committed to growth and successful entrepreneurship, Mavlyuda has used each loan wisely and has repaid each with a perfect credit history. 

Currently, she is seeking a loan of 1000 USD to replace her winter inventory with summer clothing. The well-being of Mavlyuda’s family and her business are in your hands. Mavlyuda and her children are sincerely grateful for your support.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new clothing for spring and summer

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is a 35-year-old married man with two children.  He runs a mobile money transfer business (M-Pesa) in the Kibera slums.  He also sells mobile air time and has employed two people in his business which has been running for five years.  He was formerly distributing bread before he started this business. He also earns extra income from his retail shop.  

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to support his family and be financially independent.   He has requested Kes. 60,000 to add cash float, air time cards and buy cereals.  He hopes to open other outlets for his business in the future.

loans.use: Add cash float to money transfer business

loans.name: Niginamo

texts.en:
H. Niginamo is a small-scale entrepreneur from Dushanbe, Tajikistan. She is married and the loving mother of three children, who are the reason for her daily fight for a better life. 

Niginamo sells women's clothing in the market. She is a very hard-working woman. She always achieves her goals and overcomes different challenges with natural optimism. She is requesting a loan of 800 USD to re-stock her inventory. She is hoping to purchase more merchandise at affordable wholesale prices for further retail sale. 

The only dream of Niginamo is to ensure her children a good education and to make them happy. We believe Niginamo’s integrity and the consistent growth of her venture in the past years can guarantee further stable expansion of her trade and timely loan repayment.

It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing women's clothing to increase the range of goods

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is a 29 year old hardworking married lady who is blessed with two children. Her husband is employed while she operates a boutique shop. Previously, she sold household items. She has been running her business for two years and she has learned how to minimize costs and attract more customers. She is thankful for the training provided by Faulu Kenya. She wants to take out her first loan of Kes.50,000 from Faulu Kenya to add stock of clothes. She hopes to build rental houses in the future.

loans.use: To add stock of clothes.

loans.name: Mavdjuda

texts.en:
Mavdjuda V. is 34 years old. She is married with 3 adorable children. Mavdjuda has been able to combine her love of children with a successful business selling teenager’s clothing at a busy market in Dushanbe. She currently has one sales place at the market. Eventually, she would like to open a store in a permanent facility. She has requested a loan of $1500 USD to help purchase new inventory of clothing. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New Western culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new clothing to increase the range of goods for sale.

loans.name: Annah

texts.en: Annah I. M. is twenty-six years old. She is single and has no children yet. Her business is located at the busy town of Kakamega. She does tailoring and clothes mending. She also makes clothes and sells to her clients who are normally the local working class people and students. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is that there are a lot of people in the area doing the same kind of business , hence customers are spoilt for choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 40,000 to buy more material to make more clothes to expand her business. In the future, she hopes to open many tailoring shops. She is a very hardworking and determined lady.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials.

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en: Tabitha is a 34 year old mother of two children. She is a tailor and a dressmaker in Embakasi in Nairobi, but she was previously employed. Her husband is employed as a civil servant. She has been able to expand her business, which has been running for four years through Faulu Kenya. She has taken out one loan from Faulu Kenya in the past and she plans to take out a loan of Kes.40,000 to purchase more fabric. She hopes to have a textile industry in the future. She dreams of becoming a famous business lady in ten years.

loans.use: To add stock of fabric.

loans.name: Amudat

texts.en: Amudat is married with 3 children and she is 35 years old. To support their home, her husband also works. She sells crayfish and foodstuffs in the market in Oyo town. Crayfish is a major soup ingredient in Nigeria. She has been in this business for 6 years. Amudat is requesting a loan to purchase more crayfish and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crayfish and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Joel

texts.en: Joel is an open-air hawker in Bush Town Market in Kakamega, Kenya. He sells general household and cooking ingredients such as sugar, candy, paper, padlocks, and cooking oil. He's been in the business for 3 years, and is using his KES 48,000 to purchase more stock for his business. He's single, and in the future, he'd like to own his own shop and sell wholesale.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for general store.

loans.name: Saraa

texts.en:
Saraa is 31 years old and lives with her two daughters in Tuv province, Mongolia. She and her two daughters live together in their own house. Saraa's  two children attend a local secondary school and kindergarten. They have been living in their current home for 2 years. Saraa operates a food trading business in her town in partnership with her sister. Saraa sells variety of foods out of a stall at the local market. She has purchased her own plot of land with a house and yard using her business profit.

Her business is very important to her and she hopes her future earnings will improve her family's quality of life. Saraa is a very hard working and honest person and says, “My dream is to one day have my own supermarket. Furthermore, I would like to bring up my children in the proper way and to be financially ready for my two children's future life.” She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrugs loan to purchase more inventory at wholesales prices and resell them at a profit.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory at wholesale prices.

loans.name: Jeremiah

texts.en: Jeremiah is a 28 year old owner of Copytec enterprises in Kakamega, Kenya. Jeremiah has provided typesetting, laminating, binding, computer servicing, and photocopy services from his location in a busy town market at the city center for 2.5 years. He has two employees and mainly caters to schools, colleges, cybercafe owners, and other locals. Mainly, he faces challenges such as lack of steady business capital to allow him to supply a large variety of printer cartridges, and competition from other similar businesses in the same location. In 5 years Jeremiah would like his business to operate internationally and be able to purchase stock from abroad in bulk, as well as creating awareness about starting and running a business amongst his friends and relatives. He hopes to use proceeds from his business to provide a quality education for his two young boys.

loans.use: To purchase toner, printer cartridges, and stationery.

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en: Thomas is a 37 year old married man with three children. He runs a carpentry and joinery business in Kayole in Nairobi city. He employs two people who assist him in the business, which has been running for seven years. His wife does baking to earn a living. He previously took a loan of Kes.100,000 from Faulu Kenya which he used to expand his business and to educate his two children. He plans to add stock of materials in his workshop where he makes furniture. Therefore, he has requested Kes.35,000 from Faulu Kenya. He sees himself opening a furniture company in the future.

loans.use: To add stock of materials.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: additional paint for vehicles

loans.name: Rashidat

texts.en:
Rashidat is 49 years old and a mother of five. She sells vehicle engine oil and also runs a restaurant business. She has a sales girl who assists her in the business and is paid weekly.

Rashidat opens her shop every day of the week from 8 am to 6 pm. Her biggest priority is feeding the children and making sure their school fees are paid. 

Rashidat is asking for a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more engine oil, which will enable her to meet the demand of customers. She says thanks to Kiva for the wonderful initiative.

loans.use: To purchase more engine oil to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is well known as a businesswoman in Oyo state, Nigeria. She sells onions at retail prices to her customers. Her customers love patronizing her because she is friendly and hard working. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to grow her business. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more onions to sell.  She is married to a pastor and they have five children. Mary is 45 years old. She hopes to give her children a quality education. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more onions to sell

loans.name: Obed

texts.en: Obed A. is a 34-year-old boda boda (motorcycle taxi) driver from the town of Thika, in Kenya. Obed received a loan of KES 30,000 to expand his boda boda business. He faces challenges such as stiff competition from other motorcycle taxi operators. Obed is married and has two daughters, aged nine and six. He eventually wants to own many motorbikes to use in his taxi business and he envisions that he can be a market leader in five years. He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Purevjav

texts.en: Purevjav is 32 years old and lives with her three children in Tuv province, Mongolia. She and her children live together in an apartment. All three of her children attend a local secondary school. They have been living in their current home for 25 years. Purevjav operates a clothing trading business in her town in partnership with her sibling. Purevjav sells a variety of clothes out of a rental stall at the local market. She has been expanding the stall and providing for her family expenses with her business profit. Purevjav is optimistic about the future and hopes to grow her business into a stable operation. Her business is very important to her and she hopes her future earnings will continue to improve her family's quality of life. Purevjav says, “My dream is to one day have my own clothing trading store. Furthermore, I would like to bring up my children in the proper way and be financially ready for my daughter's future life.” She is requesting a 1,500,000-tugrugs loan to purchase variety of clothes at wholesale price and resell them at a profit.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes

loans.name: Sokhna

texts.en: Sokhna N. is 45 years old, married and the mother of three children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" NGOSCOP for nine years and has always paid back her loans on time. Like many other women in her village, she raises cattle and sheep, which she then sells at the grand market of nearby Bambey. In addition, she sells grain and peanuts. This loan will allow her to buy two young cattle. The revenues from selling them at the market will allow her to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase two cattle

loans.name: Aram

texts.en:
Aram Y. is 38 years old and he lives in Ijevan city. He is married and has a son and two daughters. 
Since 2000, Aram has been engaged in the shoe trading business in a rented place in Ijevan City Market Centre. At the same time, Aram and his father make shoes to order and per month, they produce approximately 50 pairs of shoes.
Aram has taken a loan three times from “Nor Horizon” and has never been delinquent in his repayments.
Aram asks for a loan of 500,000 AMD to buy spring shoes to resell.

loans.use: To buy spring shoes to resell

loans.name: George

texts.en: George is a 34-year-old married man who is blessed with two children.  He has been running a retail shop for four years in Kibera slums.  He also operates a cafeteria business.   He was a hawker before he started his businesses.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, his business has expanded and his business is still growing. He hopes to grow his business to a wholesale shop and to be a distributor of his goods. He has requested a loan of KES 40,000 to add to his stock of foodstuffs and household goods.

loans.use: Add to his stock

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice is a 34-year-old lady who is married and blessed with one child.  She has been running a grocery shop for five years. She also practices farming to increase her income. She had a tailoring business before she ventured into this business. She hopes to buy a pick-up motor vehicle to enable faster transportation of her goods.  She also dreams of being the main supplier of her products in Machakos. She has requested a loan of KES 30,000 to add to her stock of onions, tomatoes and potatoes.

loans.use: To add to her stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick I. K. is 38 years old and married. His wife sells clothes and they have six children whom they hope to give quality education to the university level. His business is located at Kakamega within a busy market. He makes sideboards, beds, sofa sets and tables and sells to mostly the teachers and local businessmen. He has been in this business for the last 12 years and has one employee. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is the increase in price of materials. He also says that there are so many people in the area doing the same kind of business so customers are not so loyal because they are spoiled by all the choices. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 15,000 to buy more timber, plywood, vanish, and velvet materials to expand business. He is very hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase timber, plywood, nails, velvet materials and vanish.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is a 39-year-old married lady who is blessed with two children who attend school. She has been distributing cakes and cookies to the area residents and to other retailers for two years.  She also gets rental income from her rental houses. She was previously an employee at Utalii hotel before she started this business. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has learned to keep proper business records. She has requested a loan of KES 30,000 to purchase raw materials like wheat flour, baking flour, salt and sugar. She describes herself as a hardworking and a royal lady.
The photo was taken while she was supplying her products to a retail shop.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients

loans.name: Aboubakrine Moussa

texts.fr:
Monsieur Aboubakrine Moussa B. est âgé de 60 ans et gère une famille composée de sa femme, ses 7 enfants et de ses 4 frères.   Spécialiste en chaussures depuis 1968, Monsieur B. est formateur en chaussures au lycée Maurice De La Fosse de Dakar. C’est par amour qu’il a embrassé ce métier et pense que  seul  l’aspect  protecteur et l’élégance sont les aspects les plus importants de son travail. Souciant de la nécessité de s’autogérer, Monsieur Aboubakrine B.  en parallèle de son activité compte mettre en place son propre atelier afin de confectionner des produits (chaussures, sac, ...etc)destinés à la vente et de former des jeunes qui n'ont pas la chance d'aller à l'école. 
Ainsi, pour l’avancement de son travail Monsieur B. souhaitait un financement de 150 000 FCFA auprès de sa caisse Jammi Xaleyi d’U-IMCEC Thiès. Cependant il compte acheter des matières premières pour les 95 000 FCFA et les 55 000 FCFA qui restent régler des besoins personnels (payer la facture d’électricité de sa maison, location…). 
Enfin tout en remerciant d’avance les prêteurs, Monsieur Aboubakrine pense que le crédit va lui permettre d’assainir ses passifs et de créer des produits (comme par exemple le sac dans la photo  qu’il a confectionné pour lui-même) destinés à la vente.
texts.en:
Mr. Aboubakrine Moussa B. is 60 years old and is in charge of a family made up of his wife, his seven children and his four brothers. A specialist in shoes since 1968, Mr. B. is a teacher of shoe-making at the Maurice De La Fosse high school in Dakar. He took up this profession out of love and believes that the protective element of shoes and their elegance are the most important aspects of his work. Concerned by the necessity to manage his affairs by himself, Mr. B. is planning to run a parallel activity by setting up his own workshop and making products (shoes, bags) to sell; he plans also to train young people who do not have the opportunity to go to school. Thus, in order to advance his work, Mr. B. would like a loan of 150,000 FCFA from his savings bank, Jammi Xaleyi, which belongs to U-IMCEC (a Senegalese association of mutual savings and loans institutions) in Thies. He is planning to buy basic materials for 55,000 FCFA, and the balance of 55,000 FCFA will be used to cover personal needs (to pay the electricity bill for his house, rent..). Finally in thanking his lenders in advance, Mr. B. thinks that the loan will allow him to settle his debts and to create products (such as the bag in the photo, which he made himself) for sale.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Get supplies of basic materials and pay expenses

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 28-year-old married man with two young children. He has owned a chocolate and sweets shop since 2006 and has seven years of experience in this occupation when he was working in a friend's shop. He cooperates with his wife to provide better living conditions for their kids. He presents his products on shelves so it is easy for his clients to choose. 

Today, Mohamad is requesting to borrow $700 to add more merchandise to increase his sales and his income.

loans.use: To add more merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more used clothes to sell to his customers

loans.name: Takku Liggueey Group

texts.fr:
Takku Liggueey  est un groupement féminin  composé de 5 femmes que sont Madame Coumba S., la présidente, Madame Nogaye N., Madame Salla D., Madame Aby N. et Madame Awa D.. Elles sont toutes de Notto une communauté rurale située dans le département de Thiès.
Banabanas ou vendeuses de légumes toutes les 5 dans le grand marché de Notto, ces femmes se sont regroupés pour mieux organiser leur secteur et s’entraider dans le travail. Elles se sont ainsi adhérées à U-IMCEC Notto depuis 2009 pour trouver des financements nécessaires pour leur commerce. Ainsi, elles demandent un montant de 375 000 FCFA  qu’elles vont partager à part égale. 
La présidente, Madame Coumba S. est âgée de 31 ans. Cette femme mariée a fait 15 ans dans ce commerce qui lui a permis de connaitre, dit-elle, l’environnement et ses composants grâce à l’activité des maraîchers. Avec sa part, elle compte renforcer son activité comme ses autres collègues. Elle entend acheter des légumes du genre carottes, choux, aubergines et maniocs. 
Enfin Madame Coumba S. qui a choisi ce métier par amour pense ce commerce lui permet d’alléger les charges de la maison.
texts.en:
Takku Liggueey is a female group composed of five women: Mrs. Coumba S., the president, Mrs. Nogaye N., Mrs. Salla D., Mrs. Aby N., and Mrs. Awa D.. They are all from Notto, a rural community in the Thiès region. Because all five women sell vegetables at the grand market in Notto, they formed a group to better organize their business and help one another with work. They thus joined U-IMCEC Notto in 2009 to find the necessary finances for their trade. So, they are asking for a loan of 375,000 FCFA which they are going to split equally. The president of Takku Liggueey, Mrs. Coumba S., is 31 years old. This married woman has been working in this trade for 15 years. She says she knows the environment and its components thanks to the market gardeners. With her part of the loan, she counts on strengthening her work like her other colleagues. She intends to buy vegetables like carrots, sprouts, eggplant and cassava. Finally, Mrs. Coumba S., who chose this work for love, thinks the trade allows her to lighten her household load.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock up on merchandise
